He has short dark hair parted in the middle and maintains a neutral expression.]] '''Site John McCrae''' ({{lang-nl|Kanaaldijk - site John McCrae}}) is a [[World War I]] memorial site near [[Ypres]], [[Belgium]]. It is named after the Canadian physician [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[John McCrae]], [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] (1872–1918), author of the famous poem "[[In Flanders Fields]]", which he composed while serving at this site in 1915.
==Location== Site John McCrae is located directly adjacent to the [[Ieperlee]] (Ypres Canal), about halfway in between the centre of Ypres and the centre of [[Boezinge]], about 2.5 km from each. The memorial site is set in between Diksmuidseweg (N369) in the west and the [[Ieperlee]] in the east, and can - for the purpose of orientation - be roughly divided into four sections: The south-west of the site is now occupied by the [[Essex Farm Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery|Essex Farm CWGC Cemetery]]. The north-western quarter is privately used as farmland, while the north-east and south-east are partially wooded and dominated by the artificially constructed earthen ridge of the [[Levee|embankment]], which runs parallel to the [[Ieperlee]]. In the centre of the memorial site are the remains of concrete bunkers used by a British Advanced Dressing Station, while separate memorials to [[John McCrae]] and his poem ''[[In Flanders Fields]]'' are just to the east of these bunkers. In the north-eastern quarter of the memorial site are the remains of emergency housing provided by the Belgian government for the local population during the [[First World War]], while the most visible landmark in the south-eastern quarter of the site is the memorial to the [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division]] on the ridge of the dyke.
==Landmarks == ===British Advanced Dressing Station=== [[File:Essex Farm Field Dressing Station.jpg|thumb|Bunkers used by the Advanced Dressing Station]] During the [[First World War]], the [[Ieperlee]] was part of the frontline. It linked the [[Ypres Salient]], held by the French and English, to the [[Yser Front]], held by the Belgian Army. Because of its location close to the frontline, the canal bank was chosen by the British as the site of an [[field hospital|Advanced Dressing Station]]. During the [[Second Battle of Ypres]] in April-May 1915, a first basic medical station for British Army casualties was established in rough dugouts cut into the western bank of the canal. The original crude dugouts in the canal bank were expanded into a dressing station by 1917 and reinforced with concrete. They gradually developed into a series of rooms and a larger medical station was built up with huts to cope with larger numbers of wounded. The Advanced Dressing Station was also equipped with a railway line, narrow gauge railway lines and camps to cope with the huge number of wounded soldiers from the northern part of the [[Ypres Salient]].<ref>[http://www.greatwar.co.uk/ypres-salient/remains-bunkers-essex-farm-ads.htm www.greatwar.co.uk]</ref> The land south of the farm known by Allied soldiers as "Essex Farm" was used as a [[Essex Farm Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery|dressing station cemetery]] from April 1915 to August 1917. The [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division]] buried their dead of 1915 in Plot I. Many burials were made without definite plan.<ref name="CWGC">[http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/15800/ESSEX%20FARM%20CEMETERY CWGC: Essex Farm Cemetery, access date 2015-05-12]</ref>
===Memorials to ''In Flanders Fields''=== [[File:In Flanders fields and other poems, handwritten.png|thumb|right|An autographed copy of the poem from ''In Flanders Fields and Other Poems''.]] {{Main|In Flanders Fields}} [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[John McCrae]], [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] fought in the [[second battle of Ypres]] when the German army launched one of the first [[Chemical weapons in World War I|chemical attacks]] in the history of war. They attacked the Canadian position with [[chlorine#Use as a weapon|chlorine gas]] on 22 April 1915, but were unable to break through the Canadian line, which held for over two weeks. In a letter written to his mother, McCrae described the battle as a "nightmare": "For seventeen days and seventeen nights none of us have had our clothes off, nor our boots even, except occasionally. In all that time while I was awake, gunfire and rifle fire never ceased for sixty seconds.... And behind it all was the constant background of the sights of the dead, the wounded, the maimed, and a terrible anxiety lest the line should give way."<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.veterans.gc.ca/eng/history/firstwar/mccrae/flanders |title=In Flanders Fields |publisher=Veterans Affairs Canada |accessdate=2012-02-06}}</ref>
Alexis Helmer, a close friend, was killed during the battle on May 2. McCrae performed the burial service himself, at which time he noted how [[poppy|poppies]] quickly grew around the graves of those who died at Ypres. The next day, he composed the poem while sitting in the back of an ambulance<ref>{{harvnb|Gillmor|2001|p=93}}</ref><ref name="CWGC">[http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/15800/ESSEX%20FARM%20CEMETERY CWGC: Essex Farm Cemetery, access date 2015-05-12]</ref> at the Essex Farm Advanced Dressing Station.
There are two memorials to McCrae and his poem on the site: a small [[lozenge]]-shaped plaque ([[List of World War I memorials and cemeteries in Flanders|Albertina Marker]]) just off Diksmuidseweg (N369) and a larger wall tablet close to the bunkers used by the Advanced Dressing Station.
===49th Infantry Division Memorial=== [[File:Ypres Kanaaldijk Site John McCrae12.jpg|thumb|49th Infantry Division Memorial]] {{Main|49th (West Riding) Infantry Division}} The [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division]] Memorial is immediately behind the cemetery, on top of the canal bank.<ref name="CWGC">[http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/15800/ESSEX%20FARM%20CEMETERY CWGC: Essex Farm Cemetery, access date 2015-05-12]</ref> It is shaped like an obelisk and accessed via a flight of stairs leading up the canal bank from [[Essex Farm Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery]].
===Essex Farm CWGC Cemetery === [[File:Ypres Kanaaldijk Site John McCrae11.jpg|thumb|Essex Farm CWGC Cemetery]] {{Main|Essex Farm Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery}} This [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]] [[war cemetery]] was designed by Sir [[Reginald Blomfield]]. There are 1,200 servicemen of the First World War buried or commemorated in [[Essex Farm Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery|Essex Farm CWGC Cemetery]]. 103 of the burials are unidentified but special memorials commemorate 19 casualties known or believed to be buried among them.<ref>http://www.cwgc.org/find-a-cemetery/cemetery/15800/ESSEX%20FARM%20CEMETERY</ref>
===Belgian emergency housing === In the north-eastern quarter of the memorial site, partially hidden by trees, are the remains of former shelters that were used as emergency housing provided by the [[Belgian government]] for the local population during the [[First World War]]. These were constructed using pre-fabricated curved concrete elements, covered with metal sheets and then with earth.
